stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Financial Institution Received Tinba Banking Malware
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 23 March 2015 a financial institution received and analyzed malware identified as Tiny Banker (Tinba). The Tinba file bin.exe (MD5: 53b71184a4f2a6fe5df33b40c374bfb1) can collect and send social media or other online account credentials. This instance of the malware called back to Lkycdejmfimg.com (62.213.67.125) and e-lindorff.uk (23.229.244.180).

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
A registry key was modified to enable persistence:
\REGISTRY\USER\S-1-5-21-344981575-398944299-1130229096-1000\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\"56C38E70" = C:\Users\[admin]\AppData\Roaming\56C38E70\bin.exe
These registry keys were modified to hijack a web browser:
\REGISTRY\USER\S-1-5-21-344981575-398944299-1130229096-1000\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\"ProxyEnable" = 0x00000000 \REGISTRY\USER\S-1-5-21-344981575-398944299-1130229096-1000\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\"AutoConfigURL"
The malware injects into multiple processes:
C:\Windows\System32\winver.exe C:\Windows\explorer.exe C:\Windows\System32\taskhost.exe C:\Windows\System32\dwm.exe C:\Program Files\Internet Explorer\iexplore.exe C:\Program Files\Adobe\Reader 9.0\Reader\AcroRd32.exe C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office12\WINWORD.EXE C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office12\POWERPNT.EXE C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office14\EXCEL.EXE C:\Windows\System32\rundll32.exe
This malicious file is a banking Trojan identified as Tinba (Tiny Banker). Analysis of the configuration file for the Trojan indicates this particular instance is targeting a single financial institution based in Poland, ipko.pl. While the malware appeared to target Skype, Microsoft, Google, and Facebook user credentials, it can also use form grabbing functions and load additional malware payloads. The initial delivery mechanism for this Tinba instance is unknown, although Tinba has often been distributed through the Andromeda loader, which in turn is commonly distributed through malicious spam campaigns.
Tinba communicates with a C2 site using a Domain Generation Algorithm (DGA). In this incident, Tinba called back to Lkycdejmfimg.com (62.213.67.125) then e-lindorff.uk (23.229.244.180).

This domain resolved to IP 62.213.67.125 at the time of this report. Tinba C2 domains typically follow a DGA (Domain Generation Algorithm). Data sent to the C2 is encrypted with the following Public Key:
---- BEGIN PUBLIC KEY ---- MIIBITANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQEFAAOCAQ4AMIIBCQKCAQBx7O/djAIQL8NzFbHLySlb 2xZ8MHsIkDwz7CGSohsRpSnXMNi2zYY7Ei7Cd33zlR0I+4ZFRBZ/XEWQZir/Qiif fN5wxdjwpGMJCm1ZTQlLZFk0HmTMbMdyJDcrtgqbTmFHxwaWwt5dNvaQmFFcAr5Q wFaoAcCFukbLtBx9WOwTkTaalQtR78AsQ4Wala+WzwuttJLj9Zq8XJykHcxhqHzS kRVRLn9znMAl86ZiuA/H4SSoiwtpFkRrbXGfxJf/forZZn1l3tSaQ5sT1zmrYk0V 0Lgl15LKtn54DyL/cjc6SLHCQ0iwWwqvXyzprSmIIXXJ+kgTSNsAJsZQ0epfn+ah AgMBAAE= ---- END PUBLIC KEY ----

At the time of this report, this domain resolved to IP 23.229.244.180.
This specific URI is the hosting site for an Automated Transaction System (ATS) panel associated with this Tinba instance. According to available WHOIS information, the relatively new domain was registered through a public company on 09 March 2015 and hosted from a US Data Center.
According to the report, the panel will reply with one of the following responses:
answer = {p1:'"',p2:'"',p3:'"',p4:'"',p5:'"',sta tus:"OFF",link:"ON"}
